contextId.information: The words "face" and "faces" are used to stand for the people the sentence is about. AT: "I have made you as stubborn as they are." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: I have made your face as stubborn as their faces

contextId.information: The hands and knees are synecdoches for the people themselves, AT: "They will all be terrified" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: Every hand will falter and every knee will be weak as water

contextId.information: The word "sword" is a metonym for enemy armies who will attack with their swords. AT: "I will send armies to pursue them with swords" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: I will send out a sword after them

contextId.information: Here the word "heart" represents the person and his emotions. AT: "discourage the righteous person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: discourage the heart of the righteous person

contextId.information: God's hand refers to what he does. AT: "I will work against him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: I will reach out with my hand against him

contextId.information: Here the word "eye" represents the person who sees. AT: "Nobody who saw you had compassion for you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: No eye had compassion for you

contextId.information: Here the words "hands" represent the people who work with their hands. The words "poor" and "needy" emphasize that these are people who cannot help themselves. AT: "She did not help the people who could not help themselves." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: She did not strengthen the hands of the poor and needy people

contextId.information: Here the word "soul" represents the person. AT: "The person who sins" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: The soul who sins

contextId.information: Here "hand" represents the person and his actions. Possible meanings are 1) he does not harm poor people by his actions. AT: "he does not harm poor people" or 2) the word "poor" can be translated as "iniquity," meaning that the person does not commit iniquity. AT: "he refrains from committing iniquity" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: he draws his hand back from the poor

contextId.information: Here the word "eyes" represents the person who looks to the idols to worship them. AT: "They were longing after their fathers' idols" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: Their eyes were longing after their fathers' idols

contextId.information: Here the word "face" represents the person. By mentioning the opposite directions, Yahweh refers to everyone who lives in the north, in the south, and everywhere in between. AT: "every person who lives in that area" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
contextId.quote: every face from the south to the north

contextId.information: Here the Israelites are referred to by their "eyes" to emphasize what they see. AT: "before them" or "before the Israelite people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: before their eyes

contextId.information: This speaks of people becoming afraid as if their hearts were fainting. Also, this speaks of being fearful as faints. AT: "for everyone will become fearful" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: for every heart will faint away

contextId.information: Here the whole person is referred to by his "hands." AT: "will you be strong" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: will your hands be strong

contextId.information: This refers to the house in general. The reference to the "middle" emphasizes that what was done happened openly in the temple and defiled the whole place. AT: "in my own house" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: the middle of my house

contextId.information: The army of Babylon is referred to by its leader. AT: "the army of the king of Babylon" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: the king of Babylon has besieged

contextId.information: This refers to Ezekiel's wife. Yahweh refers to Ezekiel by the part of his body he uses to see his wife. AT: "your wife, whom you love very much" (UDB) (See [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: the desire of your eyes

contextId.information: Here Yahweh refers to the people by their "soul" to emphasize their inner feelings. AT: "the building that you truly love" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: the yearning of your soul

contextId.information: This can be stated in active form.  This speaks of Ezekiel being given understanding and the ability to speak is if their mouth were being opened. AT: "I will open your mouth" or "you will know what to say" or "I will cause you to know what to say" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: your mouth will be opened up

contextId.information: Here "man's foot" represents people. AT: "No man will walk through the land of Egypt" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: No man's foot will pass through it

contextId.information: Here "mountains" represents the whole land of Israel. The phrases "have been destroyed" and "have been given over" can be stated in active form. AT: "against the land of Israel ... It is in ruins; we can now devour it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: against the mountains of Israel ... They have been destroyed; they have been given over to us to devour

contextId.information: Here, "lips" and "tongues" represent people speaking. AT: "people are saying bad things about you, and the nations are telling bad stories about you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: you have been the subject of slanderous lips and tongues, and of people's stories

contextId.information: Here "you" refers to the mountain of Israel which also represents the trees on the mountain that will grow fruit. AT: "your trees will grow will grow branches and bear fruit" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: you will grow branches and bear fruit
